axioms.name: Transformation as Universal Grammar
axioms.statement: Transformation is the universal grammar of narrative. All stories are fundamentally about change; the metamorphosis literalizes what other narratives metaphorize. Form follows flux.

axioms.name: Universal Connection
axioms.statement: All things connect; the poet's task is revealing the connection. The carmen perpetuum ('continuous song') demonstrates that apparently disparate myths share hidden linkages through genealogy, geography, theme, or speaker.

axioms.name: Tonal Range as Mastery
axioms.statement: Tonal range demonstrates mastery; monotony signals limitation. The movement from horror to comedy to pathos within a single work proves command over the full spectrum of human experience.

axioms.name: Aetiological Justification
axioms.statement: Aetiology justifies anthology. Each transformation explains something about the present world (why the laurel is Apollo's tree, why spiders weave), providing functional coherence to disparate tales.

axioms.name: Permeable Narrator Boundary
axioms.statement: The boundary between teller and tale is permeable. Embedded narrators (Orpheus, the Muses, Ulysses) become characters whose telling transforms them and their listeners.

levels.name: Carmen Perpetuum
levels.description: The complete work as continuous unbroken song
elements: Must span from cosmic creation to present day

levels.name: Myth Unit
elements: Must contain at least one metamorphosis

core_algorithms.name: Metamorphic Logic Algorithm
core_algorithms.purpose: Execute Ovidian transformation preserving psychological continuity
core_algorithms.pseudocode: metamorphose(subject, trigger, new_form): 1) Identify crisis from trigger; 2) Transform body parts gradually with liminal states; 3) Preserve mens (mind) and memory in new being; 4) Add aetiological explanation to world; return new_being

core_algorithms.name: Episode Clustering Algorithm
core_algorithms.purpose: Group myths into episode clusters using Ovidian linking logic
core_algorithms.pseudocode: cluster_episodes(myth_collection, max_size=7): For each myth, find strongest link to current cluster (genealogical/geographical/thematic/speaker/temporal); if link strong and cluster not full, add to cluster; else start new cluster

core_algorithms.name: Transition Mechanism
core_algorithms.purpose: Execute smooth transition between adjacent myths
core_algorithms.pseudocode: transition_between_myths(ending, beginning, links): Priority order: speaker_transition > genealogical > object_handoff > geographical > temporal > thematic; fallback: 'Meanwhile, in another part of the world...'

core_algorithms.name: Tonal Modulation Algorithm
core_algorithms.purpose: Ensure tonal variety across episode sequence
core_algorithms.pseudocode: modulate_tone(sequence): Track recent registers; flag if same register consecutive; error if same register 4+ times; calculate overall tonal range

core_algorithms.name: Embedding Protocol
core_algorithms.purpose: Create nested narrative structure with proper framing
core_algorithms.pseudocode: embed_narrative(host, content, narrator): Establish narrator authority; create frame-in transition; increment diegetic level; create frame-out; verify thematic clustering with narrator's previous tales

diagnostic_questions.question: Does each story contain at least one physical transformation?
Does the transformation preserve psychological continuity (mens pristina)?
Does the transformation explain something about the present world (aetiology)?
Is the trigger for transformation emotionally/narratively justified?
Does the collection span from origin to present?
Are myths grouped by recognizable linking principle?
Does each book contain multiple distinct episodes?
Is there variety in transformation types across the collection?
Can you identify the link between any two adjacent myths?
Do at least 3 different link types appear across the work?
Are abrupt transitions acknowledged or motivated?
Does the work touch at least 4 distinct tonal registers?
Is there contrast between adjacent episodes?
Does no single register dominate for more than 3 consecutive myths?
Do at least 2 characters serve as embedded narrators?
Do embedded narrators' tales cluster thematically?
Does embedding create productive distance for difficult content?

key_constraints: Each transformation must explain something in present world
Trigger must be justified emotional/divine cause
Never sustain one register 4+ consecutive times
transformation_types: ESCAPE_TRANSFORMATION: Agent pursued, physical escape impossible, form-change as salvation
PUNISHMENT_TRANSFORMATION: Transgression leads to divine wrath and degrading form
GRIEF_TRANSFORMATION: Unbearable loss causes gradual solidification/flow
REWARD_TRANSFORMATION: Exceptional virtue leads to elevation/immortalization
PASSION_TRANSFORMATION: Overwhelming emotion causes form to match feeling
tonal_registers: COSMIC/SUBLIME: Creation narrative, divine councils, universal transformations
HEROIC/EPIC: Battle narratives, quests, contests between mortals and gods
PATHETIC/TRAGIC: Grief narratives, doomed lovers, innocent suffering
EROTIC/SENSUAL: Love pursuits, seductions, desire narratives
HORROR/GROTESQUE: Violent transformations, monstrous births, cannibalism
COMIC/SATIRIC: Divine foolishness, bathetic deflations, ironic commentary
